update.description:
This pull request implements the functionality to allow breadcrumb robots operate as relays. See this document for additional notes:

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l0pNxFUHBcm16TQu4KAbo\_QKo6JjN-ipT2nFtkEtEhA/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l0pNxFUHBcm16TQu4KAbo_QKo6JjN-ipT2nFtkEtEhA/edit?usp=sharing)

This pull request will need a second part. In the second part, we’ll be notified when a breadcrumb robot has been spawned, and we’ll call the function introduced in this patch to update the communication model.

I did some testing on Gazebo 9 to verify the functionality:

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) without any breadcrumbs.**

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2996229744-relay_0.png)
‌

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) with one breadcrumb at vertex** `6` **\(green intersection after the yellow segment\).**

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/917970074-relay_1.png)
‌

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) with breadcrumbs at vertices** `6` **and** `26`

**\(downslope segment after the light blue turn\).**

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2305742824-relay_2.png)
‌

**Communication range from X1 \(staging area\) with breadcrumbs at vertices** `6`**,** `26` **and** `29` **\(intersection in blue color in the upper middle section from this perspective\).**

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2855853023-relay_3.png)
‌
update.title: Communication support for breadcrumbs

content.raw:
Good point. It should be enough just one time. I added in [8d70385](#!/osrf/subt/commits/8d703859f88e2b4e513f32033c2adcfcb06b9601?at=default) two optimizations:

1. Cached `PopulateVisibilityInfo()` so that the next calls don’t have to recompute it.
2. After calculating the cost of going A->B,  also store the cost of going B->A as it should be the same.

‌
content.html:
Good point. It should be enough just one time. I added in 8d70385 two optimizations:

  1. Cached PopulateVisibilityInfo() so that the next calls don’t have to recompute it.
  2. After calculating the cost of going A->B, also store the cost of going B->A as it should be the same.

‌

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l0pNxFUHBcm16TQu4KAbo\_QKo6JjN-ipT2nFtkEtEhA/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1l0pNxFUHBcm16TQu4KAbo_QKo6JjN-ipT2nFtkEtEhA/edit?usp=sharing)

This pull request will need a second part. In the second part, we’ll be notified when a breadcrumb robot has been spawned, and we’ll call the function introduced in this patch to update the communication model.

I did some testing on Gazebo 9 to verify the functionality:

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2996229744-relay_0.png)

update.title: Communication support for breadcrumbs

content.raw: just have one more question, otherwise looks good to me
content.html: just have one more question, otherwise looks good to me

content.raw: will the `PopulateVisibilityInfo()` be called everytime a new relay is spawned? If so, do you need to clear the `visibilityInfo` map before populating it again?
content.html: will the PopulateVisibilityInfo() be called everytime a new relay is spawned? If so, do you need to clear the visibilityInfo map before populating it again?

content.raw: ok, I get it now, thanks for the explanation!
content.html: ok, I get it now, thanks for the explanation!

content.raw:
**A->D**

BC is a breadcrumb or relay, so imagine that the cost is reset to `0` when you reach it. Then, you have two hops: A->B->BC and BC->D. The cost of the first hop is 3 and the cost of the second hop is 2. This heuristic takes the max, so your cost is 3.

**A->E**

BC is a breadcrumb or relay, so imagine that the cost is reset to `0` when you reach it. Then, you have two hops: A->B->BC and BC->D->E. The cost of the first hop is 3 and the cost of the second hop is 4. This heuristic takes the max, so your cost is 4.
content.html:
A->D

BC is a breadcrumb or relay, so imagine that the cost is reset to 0 when you reach it. Then, you have two hops: A->B->BC and BC->D. The cost of the first hop is 3 and the cost of the second hop is 2. This heuristic takes the max, so your cost is 3.

A->E

BC is a breadcrumb or relay, so imagine that the cost is reset to 0 when you reach it. Then, you have two hops: A->B->BC and BC->D->E. The cost of the first hop is 3 and the cost of the second hop is 4. This heuristic takes the max, so your cost is 4.

content.raw:
for `Cost(A, D): 3` so we don't need to add the cost \(2\) from `BC` to `D`?

for `Cost(A, E): 4` how are the costs added to get `4`?
content.html:
for Cost(A, D): 3 so we don't need to add the cost (2) from BC to D?

for Cost(A, E): 4 how are the costs added to get 4?
